An exercise in trivialities: Regularity of measures

measure theory
probability theory
analysis
test
Author

Thorarinn Jonmundsson

Published

June 20, 2023

Things to write about:

  • Compact sets in Hausdorff are closed 26.
  • Schilling 4.21 and 4.22
  • Relevance to probability theory and consequently statistics

The following problem can be found in Schillingâ€™s Measures, integrals and Martingales:

Exercise 1 (Schilling 4.21) Let \(X\) be a metric space and \(\mu\) be a finite measure on the Borel sets \(\mathcal{B} = \mathcal{B}(X)\). Denote the collection of the open, closed, and compact sets by \(\mathcal{O}\), \(\mathcal{F}\), and \(\mathcal{K}\) respectively. Define a family of sets \[ \Sigma := \{A \subset X : \forall \varepsilon > 0, \exists (U\in \mathcal{O}, F \in \mathcal{F}) \hskip{0.5em} \text{s.t.} \hskip{0.5em} F \subset A \subset O, \mu(U\setminus F) < \varepsilon \}. \] (i) Show that if \(A \in \Sigma\) then \(A^c \in \Sigma\). Also show that \(\mathcal{F} \subset \Sigma\). (ii) Show that \(\Sigma\) is stable under finite intersections. (iii) Show that \(\Sigma\) is a \(\sigma\)-algebra containing \(\mathcal{B}\). (iv) Show that for all \(B \in \mathcal{B}\) \[ \mu (B) = \sup _{F \subset B, F \in \mathcal{F}} \mu(F) = \inf _{O \supset B, U \in \mathcal{O}} \mu(U). \] (v) Assume there exists an increasing sequence of compact sets \(K_j\) such that \(K_j \uparrow X\). Show that \(\mu\) satisfies \[ \mu(B) = \sup _{K \subset B, K \in \mathcal{K}} \mu(K) \] (vi) Extend the equality \(\mu (B) = \sup _{F \subset B, F \in \mathcal{F}} \mu(F)\) to \(\sigma\)-finite measures.

I think this a great problem to solve because it tests if you can has you:

  • Demonstrate that a set is an algebra (closed under complements and finite intersections/unions) (i, ii)
  • That furthermore the set is a \(\sigma\)-algebra that contains the Borel sets, opening the door to the topology induced by the metric of \(X\) (iii).
  • Has you work out that measures on metric spaces have the regularity property (iv, v)
  • Extends the results to a \(\sigma\)-finite measure such as the Lebesgue measure \(\lambda\).

Solution (i). Let \(A \in \Sigma\) and \(\varepsilon > 0\). Then there exist sets \(F\in \mathcal{F}, U \in \mathcal{O}\) such that \(F \subset A \subset O\) and \(\mu (U \setminus F) < \varepsilon\). Since \(F\) is closed, \(F^c\) is an open set. Similarly, \(U^c\) is a closed set. From elementary set theory we have \(O^c \subset A^c \subset F^c\) and the monotone property of measures then gives us \[ \mu(F^c\setminus O^c) = \mu(X\setminus F) - \mu(X\setminus O) = \mu (O \setminus F) < \varepsilon, \] so \(A^c \in \Sigma\).

Let \(F \in \mathcal{F}\). Since \(X\) is a metric space, \(F\) is a \(G_{\delta}\) set and so we can write \(F = U := \bigcap _{n \in \mathbf{N}}U_n\) where \(U_n = \bigcup _{x \in F}B_d(x, \frac1n)\). As \(U_n\) decreases to \(U\), the continuity of measures yields that \(\lim _{n\to \infty}\mu (U_n/F) = \mu(U/F) = 0\). That is, for all \(\varepsilon > 0\) there exists \(N \in \mathbf{N}\) such that \(\mu(U_n/F) < \varepsilon\) for all \(n > N\). As \(F \subset F \subset U_n\), we have that \(F \in \Sigma\) and, consequently, that \(\mathcal{F} \subset \Sigma\).

Solution (ii). Let \(\{A_1, \ldots, A_n\} \subset \Sigma\) and \(\varepsilon > 0\). For each \(A_i\) there exist \(F_i \in \mathcal{F}, U_i \in \mathcal{O}\) such that \(F_i \subset A_i \subset U_i\), and \(\mu(U_i \setminus F_i) < \varepsilon/n\). Furthermore, \(\bigcap _i ^n F_i \in \mathcal{F}, \bigcap _i^n U_i \in \mathcal{O}\), and \(\bigcap _i ^n F_i \subset \bigcap _i ^n A_i \subset \bigcap _i ^n U_i\). Finally, \[ \bigcap _{i = 1}^n U_i \setminus \bigcap_{i = 1}^n F_i = \bigcap _{i = 1}^n U_i \cap \left( \bigcup _{i = 1} ^n F_i ^c\right) = \bigcup _{i = 1}^n\left( \bigcap_{i = 1} ^nU_i \cap F_i^c\right) \subset \bigcup _{i = 1}^n (U_i\cap F_i^c), \] so by the monotone property of measures \[ \mu\left(\bigcap _{i = 1}^n U_i \setminus \bigcap_{i = 1}^n F_i\right) \leq \sum _{i = 1} ^n\mu(U_i\setminus F_i) < \varepsilon. \] This shows that \(\Sigma\) is closed under finite intersections (and unions).

Solution. \(X \in \Sigma\) since \(X \subset X \subset X\) and \(\mu(X \setminus X) = 0 < \varepsilon\) for all \(\varepsilon > 0\). This, and (i) and (ii) above, shows that \(\Sigma\) is a concrete Boolean algebra. For \(\Sigma\) to be a \(\sigma\)-algebra, all there remains to do is to show that \(\Sigma\) is closed under countable unions. Let \(\varepsilon > 0\) and \(\{A_1, A_2, \ldots \} \subset \Sigma\). For each \(A_i\) we have \(F_i \in \mathcal{F}\), and \(U_i \in \mathcal{O}\), such that \(F_i \subset A_i \subset U_i\) and \(\mu(U_i\setminus F_i) < \varepsilon 2^{-i}\). Obviously \(U =: \bigcup _{i} U_i \in \mathcal{O}\) but \(F := \bigcup F_i\) is not necessarily closed. Instead we will show that a finite union \(C_n := \bigcup _{i = 1}^n F_i \in \mathcal{F}\) will suffice. Obviously, \(C_n \subset \bigcup _i A_i \subset U\) but what can we do about \(\mu (U\setminus C_n)\)?

First, as \(\mu(U\setminus C_1) < \infty\), and \(U\setminus C_n\) is a decreasing sequence of sets in \(n\) such that \[ U\setminus C_n \downarrow\bigcap _{n = 1} \left(U \setminus C_n\right) = \{x \in U, \hspace{0.25em} x \notin C_n \text{ for all } n\} = \{x \in U, \hspace{0.25em} x \notin \cup _i F_i\} = U\setminus F, \] we have by the continuity of measures that \(\lim _n \mu(U\setminus C_n) = \mu(U\setminus F)\).

Second, since \(F_i \subset U_i\) for all \(i\), we have in general \[ U \setminus F = \left(\bigcup _{i = 1}U_i\right) \setminus \left(\bigcup _{i = 1}F_i\right) = \bigcup _{j=1}\left( U_j \setminus \bigcup _{i =1}F_i\right) \subset \bigcup _{j=1}\left( U_j \setminus F_j\right). \] Thus, by the monotone property of measures, \(\mu(U\setminus F) \leq \sum _i \mu (U_i\setminus F_i) < \varepsilon\).

Now, for our \(\varepsilon\) there exists \(N \in \mathbf{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\) \[ \mu(U\setminus C_n) = \mu(U\setminus C_n) - \mu(U\setminus F) + \mu(U\setminus F) < 2\varepsilon, \] which shows \(\bigcup _i A_i \in \Sigma\) such that \(\Sigma\) closed under countable unions and is a \(\sigma\)-algebra. Lastly, as \(\mathcal{B} = \sigma(\mathcal{F})\) is the smallest \(\sigma\)-algebra that contains \(\mathcal{F}\) and \(\mathcal{F} \subset \Sigma\) we have \(\mathcal{B} \in \Sigma\).

Theorem 1 Let \((X, d)\) be a metric space. The collection \(\mathcal{B}_X := \{B_d(x, \varepsilon): x \in X, \varepsilon > 0\}\), where \(B_d(x, \varepsilon) := \{y \in X: d(x, y) < \varepsilon\}\), is a basis for a topology on \(X\). We call this topology the metric topology induced by \(d\).

Lemma 1 If \(y \in B_d(x, \varepsilon)\) then there exists \(B_d(y, \delta) \in \mathcal{B}_X\) such that \(B_d(y, \delta) \subset B_d(x, \varepsilon)\).

Proof. Let \(\varepsilon > 0\), \(B_d(x, \varepsilon) \in \mathcal{B}_X\), and \(y \in B_d(x, \varepsilon)\). Then \(d(x, y) < \varepsilon\) so let \(\delta = \varepsilon - d(x, y)\). Then for \(z \in B_d(y, \delta)\) we have \[ d(x, z) \leq d(x, y) + d(y, z) < d(x, y) + \delta = \varepsilon. \] So \(z \in B_d(x, \varepsilon)\) and \(B_d(y, \delta) \subset B_d(x, \varepsilon)\).

Proof. Let \(\varepsilon > 0\) and \(x \in X\). Then by definition of \(\mathcal{B}_X\) there exists an \(\varepsilon\)-ball \(B_d(x, \varepsilon) \in \mathcal{B}_X\). Assume now that for \(x \in X\) there exist \(B_1, B_2 \in \mathcal{B}_X\) such that \(x \in B_1 \cap B_2\). By the lemma above there exist \(\delta_1, \delta_2\) such that \(B_d(x, \delta _1) \subset B_1\) and \(B_d (x, \delta _2) \subset B_2\). If \(\delta = \min \{\delta_1, \delta_2 \}\) then \(B_d(x, \delta) \subset B_1 \cap B_2\). Thus, \(\mathcal{B}_X\) is a basis for a topology on \(X\).

Definition 1 The topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\) is a Hausdorff space if for each \(x, y \in X\), \(x \neq y\), there exist neighborhoods \(U,V\) of \(x\) and \(y\), respectively, such that \(U\cap V = \varnothing\).

Theorem 2 Let \(X\) be a topological metric space. Then \(X\) is Hausdorff.

Proof. Let \(x,y\) be distinct elements of \(X\). Then \(d(x, y) >0\). If \(\epsilon = \frac12 d(x, y)\) then \(B_d(x, \varepsilon) \cap B_d(y, \varepsilon) = \varnothing\). Assume \(z \in B_d(x, \varepsilon) \cap B_d(y, \varepsilon)\) then \(d(x, z) < \varepsilon\), \(d(y, z) < \varepsilon\) so that \(d(x, z) + d(y, z) < 2\varepsilon = d(x, y)\) which violates the triangle inequality.

Lemma 2 Let \(Y\) be a subspace \(X\). Then \(Y\) is compact if and only if every covering of \(Y\) by open sets in \(X\) contains a finite sub-collection covering \(Y\).

Proof. Assume \(Y\) is compact and \(\mathcal{A} = \{A_{\lambda}\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\) is a covering of \(Y\) by open sets in \(X\). Then the collection \(\{A_{\lambda} \cap Y | \lambda \in \Lambda\}\) is a covering of \(Y\) by open sets in \(Y\). Since \(Y\) is compact there exists a finite sub-collection \(\{A_{\lambda_1} \cap Y, \ldots, A_{\lambda _n}\cap Y\}\) which covers \(Y\). Consequently, the sub-collection \(\{A_{\lambda _1}, \ldots , A_{\lambda _n}\}\) is a sub-collection of \(\mathcal{A}\) that covers \(Y\).

Assume that the converse holds. Let \(\mathcal{A}' = \{A'_{\lambda}\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\) be a covering of \(Y\) by open sets in \(Y\). For each \(\lambda\), choose \(A_\lambda\) open in \(X\) such that \(A'_{\lambda} = A_\lambda \cap Y\). Then \(\mathcal{A} = \{A_{\lambda}\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\) is a covering of \(Y\) by open sets in \(X\) which admits a finite sub-cover \(\{A_{\lambda _1}, \ldots , A_{\lambda _n}\}\) by the assumed hypothesis. Thus, \(\{A'_{\lambda _1}, \ldots , A'_{\lambda _n}\}\) is a finite sub-collection of \(\mathcal{A}'\) that covers \(Y\).

Theorem 3 Every compact subspace of a Hausdorff space \(X\) is closed.

Proof. Let \(Y\) be a compact subspace of \(X\) and consider \(X \setminus Y\). For \(x \in X\setminus Y\)

Definition 2 A subset \(A\) of a space \(X\) is called a \(G_{\delta}\) in \(X\) if it equals the intersection of a countable collection of open subsets of \(X\).

Proposition 1 Let \((X, d)\) be a metric space. Then each closed set \(F \subset X\) is a \(G_{\delta}\) set.

Proof. Assume that \(F \subset X\) is closed and consider the open set \(U_n := \bigcup _{x \in F}B_d(x, \frac1n)\). Our claim follows if \(F = \bigcap _{n \in \mathbf{N}} U_n\). We have by definition that \(F \subset U_n\) for all \(n\) so \(F \subset \bigcap _{n \in \mathbf{N}}U_n\). Let \(x \in \bigcap _{n \in \mathbf{N}} U_n\). Then \(x \in U_n\) for all \(n \in \mathbf{N}\). By definition, we can find \(x_n \in F\) such that \(d(x, x_n) < 1/n\). The sequence \((x_n)\) converges to \(x\), and as \(F\) is closed, it contains all of its limit points. Thus, \(x \in F\) and \(\bigcap _{n \in \mathbf{N}}U_n \subset F\).
